JUDGES: András Sajó;David Thór Björgvinsson;Françoise Tulkens;Giorgio Malinverni;Guido Raimondi;Paulo Pinto De Albuquerque
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and is currently serving his sentence in ORG ( kazneno - popravni zavod ) . He was represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG in GPE , GPE , found the applicant guilty of murder and illegal possession of firearms , and sentenced him to CARDINAL years’ and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date thereafter this judgment became final .

CARDINAL . The applicant started serving his sentence in GPE , but on DATE and upon his own request he was transferred to the ORG , pursuant to the Agreement concluded between GPE and ORG in GPE ( hereinafter “ the Agreement ” ; see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was transferred once again , this time to ORG .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the applicant filed a request to be transferred back to a prison in GPE based on LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Directorate for ORG ( hereinafter “ the Directorate ” ) , as a department within ORG ( see LAW at paragraph CARDINAL below ) , rejected this request , noting that it had been based on family - related and health reasons . The ORG firstly observed that the applicant had only complained about the pain in his ankles , in which respect he had been duly provided with adequate medication . Secondly , ORG had its own prison hospital and , if needed , the applicant could also be taken to other medical institutions outside of the penitentiary . Thirdly , ORG was the closest prison to GPE , which was where the applicant ’s family lived . Fourthly , ORG was best placed to secure the applicant ’s rehabilitation . Finally , the Agreement did not establish the applicant ’s “ right to be transferred ” to a prison of his choice . On the contrary , any transfer depended on the consent of the parties to LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed a fresh request to be transferred to GPE . Therein he explained that his entire family lived there and could not afford to visit him on a regular basis in LOC , nor for that matter , in view of the postal costs involved , even send him packages . The applicant further maintained that the quality of medical services provided in ORG was not adequate .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG rejected this transfer request . For the most part , it restated the reasons given on DATE , adding , inter alia , that the applicant had had regular contact with his family , albeit with some “ technical ” difficulties recently . Lastly , the ORG noted that family reasons could not be decisive in the assessment of a transfer request , and recalled that the applicant had initially been transferred from GPE upon his own request .

CARDINAL . On DATE , not having yet received the ORG ’s decision of CARDINAL DATE and relying on LAW DATE and LAW ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) , the applicant filed an appeal with the Minister of ORG wherein , inter alia , he complained about the failure of the ORG to consider his request of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . Having been served with the ORG ’s decision of CARDINAL DATE , on DATE the applicant filed an appeal with the Minister of ORG against it . Therein he stated that : ( i ) the ORG was not competent to consider the transfer request ; ( ii ) it should instead have properly been examined by another department within ORG ; ( iii ) the ORG had not complied with the procedures set forth in the ORG ; and ( iv ) the impugned reasoning was incoherent since the applicant ’s family lived in GPE , QUANTITY from LOC , and had had to negotiate a certain administrative procedure whenever leaving its territory .
CARDINAL . It would seem that on DATE the applicant filed another submission with the Minister of ORG in support of his appeal of DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE , and in view of the ORG ’s ruling of CARDINAL DATE , ORG rejected the applicant ’s appeal of CARDINAL DATE , deeming it moot . The appeal of DATE is apparently still pending .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant started a hunger strike , seeking his transfer to a prison in GPE .
CARDINAL . As of CARDINAL DATE the applicant also refused to take any water .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant discontinued the strike altogether .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant again started a hunger strike , seeking his transfer to GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE , following respiratory , kidney and orientation problems , as well as weight loss ( QUANTITY in all ) , the applicant discontinued the hunger strike .
CARDINAL . NORP However , on DATE , having received the ORG ’s decision of CARDINAL DATE , the applicant decided to resume the strike , which included his refusal to take either food or water .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant thereafter apparently lost consciousness on several occasions , received an infusion and experienced kidney pains .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant informed his lawyer that , fearing even more serious consequences , he had started taking water and would discontinue his hunger strike shortly .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant ’s lawyer informed the court that his client had indeed discontinued the strike altogether .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant maintained that throughout the strikes referred to above , he had been examined by the prison doctor on a DATE basis , but that when he had needed urgent medical assistance no such assistance had been provided .

CARDINAL . The applicant seems to have also been subjected to blood tests periodically , as well as to blood pressure and weight monitoring . The applicant was repeatedly warned by the prison medical staff that the strike was seriously endangering his health .
CARDINAL . Lastly , the applicant stated that it was never his intention to commit suicide , but merely to be transferred to a prison in GPE .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of this LAW read as follows :
“ This Act governs , unless specifically provided otherwise by law , the procedure of enforcement of criminal sanctions ... ”
“ ... [ Convicted persons ] are entitled to the protection of fundamental rights guaranteed by LAW , ratified international agreements , generally accepted rules of international law , and LAW . ”
“ ... [ Convicted persons are entitled to ] ... judicial review of individual ... [ decisions ] ... related to their rights and duties , in accordance with the provisions of this LAW .
“ The Directorate for the Enforcement of Criminal Sanctions ... [ hereinafter ‘ the ORG ] ... shall organise , implement and supervise the enforcement of imprisonment ...
The ... [ Directorate ] ... is an administrative authority within ORG of GPE . ”
“ Convicted persons are entitled to receive visits from ... [ their family members and others in accordance with the conditions set forth by LAW ] ... ”
“ Convicted persons shall have the right to receive packages ... ”
“ Convicted persons are entitled to medical care according to the general rules on health care , as well as the provisions of this LAW .
Convicted persons who can not receive adequate medical treatment ... [ in prison ] ... shall be transferred to ORG or another health [ care ] institution ... ”
“ Medical treatment of a convicted person may only be effected with his consent .
Forced feeding of a convicted person shall not be allowed .
Exceptionally , if a convicted person seriously impairs his health or his life , by refusing medical treatment or food , ... measures shall be applied as determined by a doctor . ”
“ The [ prison ] doctor ... shall be obliged to :
( CARDINAL ) examine on a DATE basis a convicted person who is ill or is refusing food or water ... ”
“ A convicted person mаy , for the purpose of exercising his rights , file a request with ... [ a person authorised by the prison to deal with the matter at issue ] ...
The [ authorised ] person referred to in paragraph CARDINAL of this Article must , within DATE as of receipt of the request , provide the convicted person with a written and reasoned response .
A convicted person shall have the right to lodge a complaint with the prison governor concerning any breach or irregularity suffered by him whilst in prison .
The prison governor , or another person authorised by him , shall consider the convicted person ’s complaint , and shall decide upon it within DATE .
A convicted person who receives no such ... [ decision ] ... or is not satisfied with the decision rendered shall have the right to file an appeal with the Head of the ORG within DATE .
The Head of the ORG shall be obliged to rule on this appeal within DATE as of its receipt . ”
“ Should a convicted person consider that his right has been breached by the prison governor personally , he may file a complaint with the Head of the ORG .

Should the Head of the ORG , or another person authorised by him , ascertain that the complaint was not brought for reasons cited in paragraph CARDINAL [ of this Article ] , the complaint shall be forwarded to [ another ] competent body and the convicted person shall be informed thereof .

The Head of the ORG , or another person authorised by him , may investigate the merits of the complaint by means of looking into the relevant prison records , [ and/or ] by interviewing the prison governor [ , ] ... the prison staff ... [ or ] the convicted person concerned ... [ , as well as ] ... other convicted persons without the presence of prison staff .
Should the complaint be deemed well - founded , the Head of the ORG shall order that the breach of the convicted person ’s right be rectified . ”

Should [ the Head of the ORG ] consider that the breach of a convicted person ’s right was caused by the actions of a member of the prison staff , ... [ he ] ... shall inform in writing the prison governor , as well as the authorised prison supervisor , and , should he consider that the breach was caused by the action of the prison governor personally , he shall [ likewise ] inform the authorised prison supervisor . ”
“ A convicted person shall have the right to complain to the authorised prison supervisor , without the presence of prison staff .
The content of the complaint shall be confidential . ”

“ Upon request of a convicted person or the proposal of the prison governor , and where there are good reasons for so doing , the Head of the ORG may transfer the convicted person from one institution to another .
The Head of the ORG may [ also ] , for reasons of security , transfer a convicted person ex officio .

A convicted person may file an appeal against the decision of the Head of the ORG referred to in DATE and QUANTITY of this Article with the Minister of Justice , within DATE as of ... [ its receipt ] ... An appeal against the decision of the Head of the ORG shall not postpone its enforcement . ”

“ A convicted person whose transfer request has been rejected may not re - submit the request before DATE have elapsed following the adoption of the decision of the Head of the ORG in response to his earlier request . ”
“ A convicted person shall be entitled to judicial recourse against the final decision ... limiting or violating one of his rights set forth under LAW .
Judicial recourse referred to in paragraph CARDINAL of this Article shall be secured through an administrative dispute . ”
“ An action seeking judicial redress shall be filed within DATE as of receipt of the decision in question .
The court of competent jurisdiction shall rule on the action referred to in paragraph CARDINAL of this Article within DATE as of its receipt . ”

“ The enforcement of detention [ in an ongoing criminal case ] is subject to supervision by the president of ORG that has jurisdiction for the territory where the main premises of the detention facility are located . ”

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that in simple matters an administrative body shall be obliged to issue a decision within DATE as of when the claimant lodged his or her request . In all other cases , the administrative body shall render a decision within DATE thereof .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL enables the claimant whose request has not been decided within the periods established in the previous paragraph to lodge an appeal as if his or her request has been denied . Where an appeal is not allowed , the claimant shall have the right to directly initiate an administrative dispute .

CARDINAL . Articles DATE and CARDINAL provide , inter alia , that an “ administrative act ” is an act / decision adopted by a ORG body in the determination of one ’s rights and obligations concerning “ an administrative matter ” .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that administrative disputes shall be adjudicated by ORG .

CARDINAL . Articles DATE and CARDINAL provide , inter alia , that an administrative dispute may be instituted against an administrative act / decision rendered at second instance , as well as against one issued at first instance should no appeal lie against it . Moreover , an administrative dispute may also be instituted , under conditions set forth by this LAW , in situations where a competent ORG body has failed to decide on a party ’s request or has failed to rule on appeal at second instance .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that should an appellate body fail to issue a decision upon a claimant ’s appeal within DATE the claimant may repeat the request , and if the appellate body declines to rule within DATE the claimant may institute an administrative dispute .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that should a first instance administrative body fail to issue a decision upon the claimant ’s request within a period provided in ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , in matters where an appeal has been excluded , the claimant may repeat the request and if the first instance body declines to rule within DATE the claimant may institute an administrative dispute before a court of law .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that the court shall consider the lawfulness ( zakonitost ) of the impugned administrative decision , as well as any reasons for its possible nullity ( ništavost ) .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that should the court rule in favour of the claimant , the impugned administrative decision shall be quashed fully or partially , and the matter shall be remitted to the competent administrative authority for re - examination .

CARDINAL . Articles DATE provides , inter alia , that should the court rule in favour of the claimant , it shall also , where the established facts of the case and its nature so warrant , have the power to decide on the merits of the claimant ’s original request ( spor pune jurisdikcije ) .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that the court may not rule on the merits in cases where an administrative decision has been adopted by the competent body in the exercise of its discretion .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that in cases where repeated administrative proceedings , following the quashing of an impugned decision adopted earlier , would cause the claimant serious harm , the court shall be obliged to rule on the merits of the claimant ’s original request , providing that the relevant facts have been established before the court itself .

CARDINAL . DATE provides that where an administrative dispute has been brought under LAW the court shall , should it rule in favour of the claimant , order the administrative body in question to decide upon the claimant ’s original request . However , should the established facts of the case and its nature make it possible , the court shall also have the power to decide on the merits thereof .

CARDINAL . ORG has frequently considered , on their substance , requests filed by convicted persons , involving various issues regulated by ORG ( see , for example , judgments U. nos . CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provides that a “ constitutional appeal may be lodged against individual decisions or actions of ORG bodies or organisations exercising delegated public powers which violate or deny human or minority rights and freedoms guaranteed by LAW , if other legal remedies for their protection have already been exhausted or have not been prescribed . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of this LAW read as follows :
“ The decisions of the Constitutional Court shall be final , enforceable and binding . ”

“ A constitutional appeal may be lodged against an individual decision or an action of a ORG body or an organisation exercising delegated public powers which violates or denies human or minority rights and freedoms guaranteed by the LAW , if other legal remedies have already been exhausted or have not been prescribed or where the right to their judicial protection has been excluded by law .
A constitutional appeal may be lodged even if all available remedies have not been exhausted in the event of a breach of an applicant ’s right to a trial within a reasonable time . ”

“ A constitutional appeal may be lodged by any individual who believes that any of his or her human or minority rights or freedoms guaranteed by LAW have been violated or denied by an individual decision or an action of a State body or an organisation exercising delegated public powers . ”
“ A constitutional appeal may be lodged within DATE of receipt of the individual decision or the date of commission of the actions ... [ in question ] ... ”

“ When ORG finds that an ... individual decision or action has violated or denied a human or minority right or a freedom guaranteed by LAW , it shall annul the ... decision in question or ban the continuation of such action or order the implementation of other specific measures as well as the removal of all adverse consequences within a specified period of time .

The decision of ORG accepting a constitutional appeal shall constitute a legal basis for requesting compensation or the removal of other adverse consequences before a competent body , in accordance with the law . ”

“ ... [ An applicant who has obtained a ORG decision in his or her favour ] .. , may lodge a compensation claim with ORG in order to reach an agreement in respect of the amount ... [ of compensation to be awarded ] ...

If ORG does not rule favourably in respect of a compensation claim or fails to issue a decision within DATE from the date of its submission , the applicant may file a civil claim for damages before the competent court . If only partial agreement has been achieved , a civil claim may be filed in respect of the remainder of the amount sought .
The composition and operation of ORG shall be regulated by the Minister of Justice . ”

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that a convicted person may be transferred from a prison supervised by CARDINAL party to the ORG to a prison supervised by the other party . The convicted person at issue shall be entitled to express his interest to be transferred in accordance with the LAW .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provides that the transfer may formally be requested by CARDINAL of the parties to the Agreement .

CARDINAL . Under LAW , a convicted person may be transferred to GPE if , inter alia , the following conditions are met : ( i ) the criminal offence is punishable by the criminal law of both parties ; ( ii ) the sentencing judgment is final ; ( iii ) the convicted person still has DATE of the sentence to serve ; and ( iv ) the convicted person , as well as the parties to the Agreement , have all consented to the transfer in question . It is lastly stated that when it comes to transfers of convicted persons to GPE , special priority shall be granted to those who were born in GPE , as well as those whose family members live there .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that all convicted persons in respect of whom the Agreement may be applicable shall be informed thereof .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that a convicted person shall be informed , in writing , about any and all decisions adopted by the parties to the Agreement in respect of the transfer .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provides that the Agreement shall be applicable to criminal sanctions imposed before as well as after its entry into force .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that the Agreement shall enter into force on the date of its signature by the parties .
CARDINAL . Rule CARDINAL provides that “ [ p]risoners shall be allocated , as far as possible , to prisons close to their homes or places of social rehabilitation ” .
CARDINAL . Rule CARDINAL provides that “ [ as ] far as possible , prisoners shall be consulted about their initial allocation and any subsequent transfer from CARDINAL prison to another ” .
